item.label: brg00016661fe2c19bee_B329A4240B414D96A05D4541901651CF076
item.title: Explain why the following series of steps is not an algorithm.

material.mattext:
Explain why the following series of steps is not an algorithm.
Washing the dog
1. Rinse
2. Lather
3. Repeat

Answer:
The steps keep repeating forever because there is no way for the algorithm to stop. (Also, it is a poor algorithm because the last action is lathering-you wouldn't want to leave the lather on your pet.)

item.label: brg00016661fe2c19bee_902F0A41E2FE41E094AC59A7939F9DB8078
item.title: Explain two real-life examples of adverse consequences caused by uncorrected software errors.

material.mattext: Explain two real-life examples of adverse consequences caused by uncorrected software errors.

Answer:
A) An error in the control software of a jet fighter caused it to flip upside down the first time it flew across the equator.
B) A rocket launch went out of control and had to be destroyed because a comma was typed in place of a period in its control software
C) A radiation therapy machine killed several patients because a software error caused the machine to operate at full power when the operator typed certain commands too quickly
D) An error in your word processor causes your term paper to be lost hours before it is due.
E) An error in a statistical program causes a scientist to draw an incorrect conclusion and publish a paper that later has to be withdrawn.
F) An error in a tax preparation program produces an incorrect return. leading to a fine for the taxpayer

item.label: brg00026271fe2c19bee_E90C14D7D2064EECB1291569DECE052E028
item.title: All of the following are useful software maintenance tips when modifying complex code EXCEPT

material.mattext: All of the following are useful software maintenance tips when modifying complex code EXCEPT
break a long block of code into smaller chunks that have distinct purposes
identify portions of the code that you are sure you can ignore.
focus on the code sections that are clearly related to the maintenance task
never document your updated code changes to avoid confusion.
examine how your code changes affect other parts of the application.

item.label: brg00026271fe2c19bee_552426DDA05046688A047BBD8B9473C8060
item.title: What is one technique to control the horizontal spacing of an actual output?

material.mattext: What is one technique to control the horizontal spacing of an actual output?

Answer:
Sending extra blank characters to the output stream is one way to control the horizontal spacing of the actual output. The blank character is generated by pressing the spacebar on a keyboard, a valid   character in C++.

item.label: brg00026271fe2c19bee_40C3EE2E438347679B4CD6A9E68BDF9E061
item.title: What are some uses of the backslash character (\ ) in C++ programming?

material.mattext: What are some uses of the backslash character (\          <wbr />) in C++ programming?

Answer:
A) The backslash character (\       ) is used when you want to print a string that includes a double quote by typing a backslash character and a double quote, with no space between them in the string. For example, to print the characters Al “Butch” Jones, the output statement would look like the following: cout « ”Al” \       ”Butch\       ” Jones”;. B) You can use the newline or end-of-line (EOL) character \      n to place a newline operation directly in a string. C) If you want to include a single quote mark as a char literal within an output stream, then it must also be preceded by a backslash, '\       ”.

item.label: brg00026271fe2c19bee_7E0A6157ABE24D4CB0237C136EA4F581062
item.title: What must a computer programmer do if the C++ compiler finds syntax errors in his or her program in order to run the program correctly?

material.mattext: What must a computer programmer do if the C++ compiler finds syntax errors in his or her program in order to run the program correctly?

Answer:
If the C++ compiler displays messages indicating syntax errors in the program, then the computer programmer must determine their cause, fix them in the editor, and then run the compiler program again. After the program compiles without error, then you can successfully run the program.

item.label: brg0003b111fe2c19bee_97CD3EB299294DF8906DFCEF0CD0993F076
item.title: What does the find function accomplish when operating on a string?

material.mattext: What does the find function accomplish when operating on a string?

Answer:
The find function searches a string to locate the first occurrence of a particular substring and returns an unsigned integer value (of type string: :size_type) giving the result of the search. The substring, passed as an argument to the function can be a literal string or a string expression.

item.label: brg0003b111fe2c19bee_B0379C1D67154137AF91A747D57659F9077
item.title: What are the length and size functions when applied to a string variable?

material.mattext: What are the length and size functions when applied to a string variable?

Answer:
The length and size functions, which are synonymous when applied to a string variable, returns an unsigned integer value that equals the number of characters currently in the string. While these two functions return an unsigned integer value of type string::size_type, most C++ compilers will permit you to declare the results to be of type int.

item.title: How do you convert character data from a lowercase letter to uppercase letter and vice versa?

material.mattext: How do you convert character data from a lowercase letter to uppercase letter and vice versa?

Answer:
Through the header file <cctype>, the standard library function provides two value-returning functions, toupper(ch), the uppercase equivalent of a character if the character (ch) is a lowercase letter, and tolower(ch), the lowercase equivalent of a character (ch)if ch is an uppercase letter.

item.label: brg00041ed1fe2c19bef_CC5F02F7A8544A61819AE242C851A3DC061
item.title: What is the main advantage of having a program input its data rather than writing all the data values as constants in the program?

material.mattext: What is the main advantage of having a program input its data rather than writing all the data values as constants in the program?

Answer:
The main advantage of having a program input its data rather than writing all of the values as constants is that the program does not have to be changed when a new set of data needs to be run through it. If all values were declared as const data, those values would have to be modified and the program recompiled every time it was run. When the program inputs the values, it can run on many different data sets without modification of the source code.

item.label: brg00041ed1fe2c19bef_389FB532B2C0486CA03CFFAFA2FFA969062
item.title: How do you generate a newline character when typing input data at the keyboard?

material.mattext: How do you generate a newline character when typing input data at the keyboard?

Answer:
A newline character is entered from the keyboard by pressing the Return or Enter key.

item.label: brg00041ed1fe2c19bef_0030222EE7404FDEB93836E12C56590D063
item.title: Define input prompt.

material.mattext:
Answer:
An input prompt is a message printed out directly before an input statement, telling the user what kind of input is expected by the input statement.

item.label: brg00041ed1fe2c19bef_72698C6CF21E42BA99CDF36875E4068B064
item.title: Define echo printing.

material.mattext:
Answer:
Echo printing refers to printing out the values of variables directly after they are read, in order to verify that the variables contain the proper values.

item.label: brg00041ed1fe2c19bef_DA92AE89CC384972AF2A05EE471B7677065
item.title: Write a program segment that reads six integer values from a file and writes them to the screen, three numbers per output line. The file is organized one value to a line.

material.mattext: Write a program segment that reads six integer values from a file and writes them to the screen, three numbers per output line. The file is organized one value to a line.

Answer:
inFile >> int1 >> int2 >> int3 >> int4 >> int5 >> int6;
cout     << int1 << ' ' << int2 << ' ' << int3 << endl
         << int4 << ' ' << int5 << ' ' << int6 << endl;

item.label: brg00041ed1fe2c19bef_4F1925C1377E4A9396A2D47E11EEDB22066

Susy
Sarah
Sunshine

item.label: brg00041ed1fe2c19bef_5386CB4E45E04F5B9A405692E5DE0397067
item.title: What should determine whether a computer programmer should print out the input values, also called echo printing, in an interactive program?

material.mattext: What should determine whether a computer programmer should print out the input values, also called echo printing, in an interactive program?

Answer:
If the users of the program have a high level of experience and the clarity of the prompts are clear, then echo printing is probably not required. If the users of the program are novices and multiple values can be input at once, echo printing should be used?

item.label: brg00041ed1fe2c19bef_8D9EA6EFBB784A00B26DCCF0E3F08D14068
item.title: What is problematic about programming the message ILLEGAL DATA VALUES!!!!!!!!! appearing on a computer screen when a user has entered a five digit part number if a four digit part number is required? How would you improve the content of this message?

material.mattext: What is problematic about programming the message ILLEGAL DATA VALUES!!!!!!!!! appearing on a computer screen when a user has entered a five digit part number if a four digit part number is required? How would you improve the content of this message?

Answer:
Such a message may well emotionally upset an inexperienced user and does not offer any constructive information. An improved message would be:
    That is not a valid number
    Part numbers must be no more than four digits long
    Please reenter the number in its proper form

item.label: brg00041ed1fe2c19bef_2162C15A6FA541A2AC6B706ECED83E42069
item.title: Define the use of functional cohesion in writing a C++ program.

material.mattext: Define the use of functional cohesion in writing a C++ program.

Answer:
The idea behind functional cohesion is that each correctly written module should do only one thing and do it well. When correctly writing a module in a C++ program, the only steps that directly address the given subproblem are concrete steps. Abstract steps are used for significant new subproblems.

item.title: True or False? The code segment

material.mattext:
True or False? The code segment
if (speed <= 40)
cout << "Too slow";
if (speed > 40 && speed <= 55)
cout << "Good speed";
if (speed > 55)
cout << "Too fast";
could be written equivalently as
if (speed <= 40)
cout << "Too slow";
else if (speed <= 55)
cout << "Good speed";
else
cout << "Too fast";

item.label: brg00054af1fe2c19bef_9171FCC3980E4CADBCB9E06B37E298C7012
item.title: True or False? If the code fragment

material.mattext:
True or False? If the code fragment
if (a >= 10)
if (a < 20)
a = a + 2;
else
a = a + 1;
is indented according to the manner in which it is executed, the correct indentation is
if (a >= 10)
if (a < 20)
   a = a + 2;
else

item.label: brg00054af1fe2c19bef_AD6A9B14C5F04CE1ACA5930CC7F583CF064
item.title: How are relational operators used in C++?

material.mattext: How are relational operators used in C++?

Answer:
In C++, a relational expression is created by placing a relational operator between two values. If the two values are in the relationship described by the operator, the expression returns True; otherwise the expression returns False.

item.label: brg00054af1fe2c19bef_DB85676419CC4910B22988914B4F06AD065
item.title: Distinguish between short-circuit evaluation and full evaluation. Which does C++ use?

material.mattext: Distinguish between short-circuit evaluation and full evaluation. Which does C++ use?

Answer:
In full evaluation, expressions are evaluated in left-to-right order until the entire expression has been evaluated. In short-circuit evaluation, evaluation stops as soon as the truth of the expression can be determined. C++ uses short uses short-circuit evaluation.

item.title: Where does the name "bool" come from?

material.mattext: Where does the name "bool" come from?

Answer:
George Boole, a 19th century mathematician described a system of logic using variables with just two values, True and False. The bool data type is named for him.

item.label: brg00054af1fe2c19bef_9B5C4B31D066474280755C24E27A267E079
item.title: What is the safest way to compare data types such as ints, floats, and chars?

material.mattext: What is the safest way to compare data types such as ints, floats, and chars?

Answer:
The safest approach is always to compare ints with ints, floats with floats, chars with chars and so on. If one mixes data types in a comparison, implicit type coercion takes place, similar to how it does in arithmetic expressions.

item.label: brg00054af1fe2c19bef_C193E1FC24AD4A6FAC1E3590DD07C847080
item.title: What does the following If-Then C ++ statement mean?

material.mattext:
What does the following If-Then C ++ statement mean?
if (age < 18)
cout << “Not an eligible “; cout <<
“voter.” << endl;

Answer:
If age is less than 18, first print “Not an eligible” and then print “voter.” If age is not less than 18, then skip the first output statement and go directly to “voter.”

item.label: brg0006c181fe2c19bef_620D362A7A8C4BC7A5C1448A857947FD062
item.title: What happens in a While loop if the incrementation phase is missing?

material.mattext: What happens in a While loop if the incrementation phase is missing?

Answer:
The loop test never changes. If the loop is entered, an infinite loop occurs. That is, the loop may never be entered if the initial loop condition evaluates to false. However, if the initial loop condition evaluates to true, the loop never terminates.

item.label: brg0006c181fe2c19bef_52E7AD31B19046A39108E1CB8364DFDD064
item.title: What is a priming read?

material.mattext:
Answer:
An initial reading of a set of data values before entry into an event-controlled loop in order to establish values for the variables in the loop expression.

item.label: brg0006c181fe2c19bef_0D61963630EC4990BFAE697D984DE1B5065
item.title: What is the purpose of a priming read?

material.mattext: What is the purpose of a priming read?

Answer:
If one or more variables in the loop expression is dependent upon input data, that value(s) must be read before the first loop test.

item.label: brg0006c181fe2c19bef_0F606D6557B04A389A7216B9F519E007066

material.mattext: What is the sentinel in a sentinel-controlled loop?

Answer:
A data value that signals that all of the data values have been read.

item.label: brg0006c181fe2c19bef_7B805984DF6A4269858007F721955437067

Answer:
The program tries to read when there is no more data.

item.label: brg0006c181fe2c19bef_1AE142C0A9E74B6F88ABCA3450C9892A076
item.title: What are the four special cases when it is good practice to test a loop?

material.mattext: What are the four special cases when it is good practice to test a loop?

Answer:
(1) when the loop is skipped entirely, (2) when the loop body is executed just once, (3) when the loop executes some normal number of times (4) when the loop fails to exit.

item.label: brg0006c181fe2c19bef_A332FAAF94454300AB007A61E2FD2312077
item.title: Describe the proper procedure for designing a nested loop structure

material.mattext: Describe the proper procedure for designing a nested loop structure

Answer:
To design a nested loop structure, begin with the outermost loop. When you get where the inner loop must appear, make it a separate module and come back to its design later.

material.mattext:
True or False? The statement
switch (n)
{
case 8 : alpha++; break;

}

alpha++;
else if (n == 3)
beta++;
else
gamma++;

item.title: True or False? The code segment

True or False? The code segment
cout << "Do you wish to continue? ";

while (response != 'Y' && response != 'N')
{
cout << "Do you wish to continue? ";
cin >> response;
}
is equivalent to the following code segment.
do
{
cout << "Do you wish to continue? ";
cin >> response;
} while (response != 'Y' && response != 'N');

item.label: brg0007f301fe2c19bf0_6A2F13B5DE1B4B37B7F416DDAE5F2713044
item.title: Write a For loop that is equivalent to the following While loop. (All variables are of type int.)

material.mattext:
Write a For loop that is equivalent to the following While loop. (All variables are of type int.)
count = -5;
while (count <= 15)
{
sum = sum + count;
count++;
}

Answer:
for (count = -5; count <= 15; count++)
sum = sum + count;

item.label: brg0007f301fe2c19bf0_226D3308D11845D6ADD5D362364B7C21070
item.title: Which of the following C ++ code illustrates pre-incrementation and which C++ code illustrates post- incremenation?

material.mattext:
Which of the following C ++ code illustrates pre-incrementation and which C++ code illustrates post- incremenation?
a) int1 = 14
int2 = ++int1; // int1 == 15 && int2 == 15
b) int1 =14
    int2 = int++; // int1 == 15 && int2 == 14

item.label: brg00084901fe2c19bf0_BAC3B9DCB6EF40139316D48A5024E123065
item.title: Write a void function that reads a specified number of float values and returns their average. The call to this function might look like GetMeanOf(5, mean);

material.mattext: Write a void function that reads a specified number of float values and returns their average. The call to this function might look like GetMeanOf(5, mean);

Answer:
void GetMeanOf( /* in */ int howMany,
                  /* out */ float& avg)
// Precondition:
//    howMany > 0
// Postcondition:
//    avg == average of howMany values read from standard
//    input device
{
   int   loopCount;    // Loop control variable
   float sum;          // Sum of the input values
   float inputValue;   // One input value
   sum = 0.0;
   loopCount = 1;
   while (loopCount <= howMany)
   {
       cin >> inputValue;
       sum = sum + inputValue;
       loopCount++;
   }
   avg = sum / float(howMany);

item.label: brg00084901fe2c19bf0_85FD7F22D5044C0AB1394995429EFF91066
item.title: Write a void function named CountUpper that counts the number of uppercase letters on one line of input. The function should return this number to the calling code in a parameter named upCount.

material.mattext: Write a void function named CountUpper that counts the number of uppercase letters on one line of input. The function should return this number to the calling code in a parameter named upCount.

Answer:
In the following code, the expression ch >= 'A' && ch <= 'Z' works properly using the ASCII character set but not EBCDIC. Chapter 8 discusses a solution to this difficulty.
void CountUpper( /* out */ int& upCount )
// Precondition:
//     Reading marker for standard input stream is at beginning of
//     a line terminated by '\ n'
// Postcondition:
//     upCount == number of uppercase letters in the input line
{
   char ch;    // An input character
   upCount = 0;
   cin.get(ch);
   while (ch != '\ n')
   {
       if (ch >= 'A' && ch <= 'Z')
          upCount++;
       cin.get(ch);
   }

item.label: brg00084901fe2c19bf0_142D3F55980F40C1804F6FF9966DD7EC067
item.title: In what case, should a module turn into a function?

material.mattext: In what case, should a module turn into a function?

Answer:
If a module is a single line only, then it generally best to write it directly in the program.

item.label: brg00084901fe2c19bf0_57ABDFA5EDF141B481E3E0A95BDD4836068
item.title: How is a function call executed with a void function?

material.mattext: How is a function call executed with a void function?

Answer:
When a function call is executed, the arguments are passed to the parameters according to their positions, left to right, and control is then transferred to the first executable statement in the function body. When the last statement in the function has executed, control returns to the point from which the function was called.

item.label: brg00084901fe2c19bf0_B1B9985AAAA94EC1A6253511E52854CF069
item.title: How are function preconditions and postconditions useful for debugging?

material.mattext: How are function preconditions and postconditions useful for debugging?

Answer:
Function preconditions and postconditions are useful for degugging by checking that the precondition of each function is true prior to a function call, and by verifying that each function correctly transforms the precondition into a postcondition.

item.label: brg00084901fe2c19bf0_57A7051D67344FAA84B3A7926FAD7CE5070
item.title: How are function preconditions and postconditions useful for testing?

material.mattext: How are function preconditions and postconditions useful for testing?

Answer:
They are useful for testing by pushing the precondition to its limits or even violating it.

item.label: brg00084901fe2c19bf0_6B105B2593DB41F2B3AE2307CD5B1AE1071
item.title: What will occur because of the following executable assertion in a C++ program?

material.mattext:
What will occur because of the following executable assertion in a C++ program?
#include <cassert>
   :
assert(studentCount > 0); average = sumOfScores / studentCount;

Answer:
If the value of the logical expression value is true, nothing happens; execution continues on to the next statement. If its value is false, execution of the program terminates immediately with a message stating (1) the assertion as it appears in the argument list, (2) the name of the file containing the program source code, and (3) the line number in the program.

int Power( /* in */ int& base,
          /* in */ int& exp )
{
int product = 1;
while (exp >= 1)
{
   product = product * base;
   exp--;
}
   return product;
}

pow = 3;
result = Power(n, pow);
cout << n << " to the power " << pow << " is " << result;

item.label: brg000945e1fe2c19bf0_4AB128C601D34E1EACF23186834712AC064
item.title: Define local variable.

material.mattext:
Answer:
A local variable is a variable declared within a block and not accessible outside of that block

item.label: brg000945e1fe2c19bf0_7F50CEF739D7452298246BFECC51216C065
item.title: Define scope.

material.mattext:
Answer:
Scope is the region of program code where it is legal to reference an identifier.

item.label: brg000945e1fe2c19bf0_60AF7A156DAC44A6BF12D71A78A073AE066
item.title: Define global variable.

material.mattext:
Answer:
A global variable is a variable declared outside all functions.

item.label: brg000945e1fe2c19bf0_1FD350EC96A54A4F9B264B6446A31E97067
item.title: Define lifetime.

material.mattext:
Answer:
Lifetime is the period of time during program execution when an identifier has memory allocated to it.

item.label: brg000945e1fe2c19bf0_245EA947F3D643FBBF88725A90D30C8F068
item.title: Define side effects.

material.mattext:
Answer:
A side effect is any effects of one function on another that are not part of the explicitly designed interface between them (for example, use of global variables, or modification in a function of a parameter that should be a value rather than a reference parameter).

item.label: brg000945e1fe2c19bf0_6B77C9AF90AA42B186B2EC91395C8F8D069
item.title: Define name precedence (name hiding).

material.mattext:
Answer:
Name precedence is the precedence that a local identifier has over a nonlocal identifier with the same name when the local identifier is referenced within its block.

item.label: brg000945e1fe2c19bf0_079453C7CCE545A5A1A802D29BF09B4F070
item.title: In the assignment operation of v = e, where v is a variable and e is an expression, how could demotion work for this assignment operation?

material.mattext: In the assignment operation of v = e, where v is a variable and e is an expression, how could demotion work for this assignment operation?

Answer:
If the type of v is “lower” than that of e, the value of e is demoted to v's type before being stored.

item.label: brg000945e1fe2c19bf0_52666DEEC4B0414E8105F618A503A528071
item.title: Assume that INT_MAX on your machine is 32767 and that you have the following function:

material.mattext:
Assume that INT_MAX on your machine is 32767 and that you have the following function:
    void Do Something( int n) {
   :
    }
    If the function is called with the statement DoSomething(50000), what occurs to the value 50,000?

Answer:
The value 50,000, which is implicitly type long because it is larger than INT_ MAX, is demoted to a completely different, smaller value that fits into an int location.

item.label: brg000945e1fe2c19bf0_7949ECFB9C54476EAC0744984B59A7ED072
item.title: Suppose you are writing a program that works with triangles. The program reads three angles as floating-point numbers. Before performing any calculations on those angles, however, you want to check that they really form a triangle by adding the angles to

material.mattext:
Suppose you are writing a program that works with triangles. The program reads three angles as floating-point numbers. Before performing any calculations on those angles, however, you want to check that they really form a triangle by adding the angles to confirm that their sum equals 180 degrees.
How would you write a Boolean function that takes the three angles as parameters and returns a Boolean result?

Answer:
#include <cmath> // For fabs()
:
bool IsTriangle(float angle1, float angle2, float angle3)
// This function returns true if its three incoming values // add up to 180 degrees, forming a valid triangle, and // false otherwise
{ return (fabs(angle1 + angle2 + angle3 – 180.0) < 0.00000001);
}

item.label: brg00101e71fe2c19bf1_30D7F159FEDE473693899F5739FF62D1027
item.title: Why is it important to know which particular character set your computer uses?

material.mattext: Why is it important to know which particular character set your computer uses?
Algorithms that work with one character set may not work with another (for example, an algorithm that converts a lowercase letter to an uppercase letter).
The same character may have different integer representations in different character sets.
The collating sequences of different character sets may not be the same.

item.label: brg00101e71fe2c19bf1_30908F78A7C1475DA879B87ED960FE1C043
item.title: You are writing a program that will add three floating-point variables x, y, and z. Their likely value ranges are as follows:

material.mattext:
You are writing a program that will add three floating-point variables x, y, and z. Their likely value ranges are as follows:
x: 0.01 to 0.9
y: 2.1E10 to 3.0E10
z: -3.5E10 to -2.2E10
In which order should you add them to obtain the most accurate answer?

Answer:
Add y and z, then add x.

item.label: brg00101e71fe2c19bf1_02D0DAA9FF5F492C8868B83BA989CD7E044
item.title: You are writing a program that will add three floating-point variables x, y, and z. Their likely value ranges are as follows:

material.mattext:
You are writing a program that will add three floating-point variables x, y, and z. Their likely value ranges are as follows:
x: 1.0 to 1.9
y: 2.1E-10 to 3.0E-10
z: -3.5E-1 to -2.2E-1
In which order should you add them to obtain the most accurate answer?

Answer:
Add z and x, then add y.

item.label: brg00101e71fe2c19bf1_81382205825941219C3117654B50B7DA048
item.title: Assume you have the following declarations:

material.mattext:
Assume you have the following declarations:
enum Days {SUN, MON, TUE, WED, THU, FRI, SAT};
days someDay;
days twoBefore;
and that someDay has been assigned some value. The variable twoBefore is to represent the day of the week that is two days before someDay. Write a statement to store the proper value into twoBefore.

Answer:
switch (someDay)
{
case SUN : twoBefore = FRI; break;
case MON : twoBefore = SAT; break;
default : twoBefore = Days(someDay - 2);
}

item.label: brg00101e71fe2c19bf1_B0A81C99BDC744AF95E18F091E34B2DC053
item.title: Define significant digits.

material.mattext:
Answer:
Significant digits are the digits from the first nonzero digit on the left to the last nonzero digit on the right (plus any zero digits that are exact).

item.label: brg00101e71fe2c19bf1_D559A2D592AB469C9600E8C6B37AA52E054
item.title: Define precision.

material.mattext:
Answer:
Precision is the term that refers to the maximum number of significant digits a computer is capable of representing

item.label: brg00101e71fe2c19bf1_09C11782580341BD9A2E4135836E13D9055
item.title: Define representational error.

material.mattext:
Answer:
Representational error is the arithmetic error that occurs when the precision of the true result of an arithmetic operation is greater than the precision of the machine.

item.label: brg00101e71fe2c19bf1_84E95D2EC82C42E3AE684564A1BDCC39056
item.title: Define underflow.

material.mattext:
Answer:
Underflow is the condition that occurs when the result of a calculation is too small to be represented in memory.

item.label: brg00101e71fe2c19bf1_9C7614D072DE458AB74972E0581B4627057
item.title: Define overflow.

material.mattext:
Answer:
Overflow is the condition that occurs when the result of a calculation is too large to be represented in memory.

item.label: brg00101e71fe2c19bf1_DEEE5CF596214BD695961E6D4E984117058
item.title: Define cancellation error.

material.mattext:
Answer:
Cancellation error is a form of representational error that occurs when numbers of widely differing sizes are added or subtracted.

item.label: brg00101e71fe2c19bf1_E1D5335D2C034A438455BF7A1FF1028F059
item.title: Define active error detection

material.mattext:
Answer:
Active error detection means that the C++ program checks for possible errors and determines an appropriate action if an error occurs

item.label: brg00101e71fe2c19bf1_48AB21834F0742FF84B8B8E117D353FD060
item.title: Define passive error detection

material.mattext:
Answer:
Passive error detection leaves it to the system to detect errors. The programmer relinquishes control of processing when an error occurs.

item.label: brg00101e71fe2c19bf1_B344CA5E761340F292BE549E33B430C7062
item.title: What is the difference between a simple data type versus a structured data type?

material.mattext: What is the difference between a simple data type versus a structured data type?

Answer:
A value in a simple data type is a single data item; it cannot be broken down into component parts. On the other hand, a structured data type is a data type in which each value can is a collection of component items. The entire collection is given a single name, however, each component cans still be accessed individually.

item.label: brg00101e71fe2c19bf1_2A766CB59EFD4B4283BA2F8209BA0017063

item.label: brg00111681fe2c19bf1_33EFD9E7AEE74BCF94345DCF4C9439CD058
item.title: Given a 5000-element, one-dimensional array beta, write a code fragment that could be used to print out the values of beta[0], beta[2], beta[4], and so forth.

material.mattext:
Given a 5000-element, one-dimensional array beta, write a code fragment that could be used to print out the values of beta[0], beta[2], beta[4], and so forth.
(All variables are of type int.)

Answer:
for (i = 0; i < 5000; i = i + 2)
cout << beta[i] << endl;
or
for (i = 0; i < 2500; i++)
cout << beta[2*i] << endl;

position1 = -1;
position2 = -1;
for (j = 0; j < 50; j++)
for (i = 0; i < 50; i++)
   if (arr[i][j] == searchValue)

     position1 = i;
     position2 = j;
   }

Answer:
It searches the array in column order for the last occurrence of searchValue.

private:          // Line 5
int n;              // Line 6
}                      // Line 7

Answer:
line 7 (there is not semicolon following the closing bracket)

item.label: brg0012ad51fe2c19bf1_07948480D32E474A8DCD3A201E67CD8B087
item.title: Given the declarations

material.mattext:
Given the declarations
enum WoodKind {HARDWOOD, SOFTWOOD};
struct Size
{
int length;
int width;
int thickness;
};
struct Wood
{
Size     dimensions;
WoodKind kind;
int      smoothSurfaces;
};
Wood oneBoard;
Wood secondBoard;
write a statement to determine whether oneBoard or secondBoard is the thicker and print the result.

Answer:
if (oneBoard.dimensions.thickness
> secondBoard.dimensions.thickness)
cout << " oneBoard is thicker than secondBoard ";
else
cout << " secondBoard is equal to or thicker than oneBoard ";

item.label: brg0012ad51fe2c19bf1_CC7E65B5E5F74C068639ADA3B801255D088
item.title: Define the term object in the context of object-oriented programming (OOP)

material.mattext: Define the term object in the context of object-oriented programming (OOP)

Answer:
In object-oriented programming (OOP), an object is a self-contained entity encapsulating data and operations on the data.

item.label: brg0012ad51fe2c19bf1_415A22CA37574825935F11D30EC41D40089
item.title: How does a C++ computer programmer apply class design principles concerning objects in order to be sure that he or she has designed a reliable unit of software?

material.mattext: How does a C++ computer programmer apply class design principles concerning objects in order to be sure that he or she has designed a reliable unit of software?

Answer:
As long as the computer programmer has designed the class so that its objects can handle any data that are consistent with the interface, he or she can be confident that it is a reliable unit of software.

item.label: brg0012ad51fe2c19bf1_A0644B369441427383317F8E887096D9090
item.title: Define an immutable object

material.mattext:
Answer:
An immutable object cannot be changed after it is instantiated

item.label: brg0012ad51fe2c19bf1_5574F51CADAE4079A99B0CD1F5F08C28091
item.title: Define a mutable object:

material.mattext:
Answer:
A mutable object has at least one function that allows the client to change the value of a data member in the object.

item.label: brg0012ad51fe2c19bf1_09F0594AB1CA49F58D7FA34CE736B0C7092
item.title: Define Unified Modeling Language (UML)

material.mattext:
Answer:
Unified Modeling Language (UML) is a made up from a combination of three different sets of graphical symbols that were in use prior to its development. These symbols have been organized and divided into UML diagrams for documenting just about every aspect of programming, from analyzing the problem to deploying the code on customer's computers.

item.label: brg00139bb1fe2c19bf2_94C204263E204219ABFC11B4FE208371044
item.title: Suppose we have a List class with private data listVals (an array holding the list items) and listLength (a variable indicating the current list length). What does the following function do?

material.mattext:
Suppose we have a List class with private data listVals (an array holding the list items) and listLength (a variable indicating the current list length). What does the following function do?
void List::Mystery( ItemType alpha, bool& result )
{
int index = 0;
while (index < listLength && alpha != listVals[index])
   index++;
result = (index < listLength);
}

Answer:
It searches a list for the first occurrence of a given item.

item.label: brg00139bb1fe2c19bf2_D085247CC5194C76BA96C2724203F775045
item.title: Suppose we have a List class with private data listVals (an array holding the list items) and listLength (a variable indicating the current list length). What does the following function do?

material.mattext:
Suppose we have a List class with private data listVals (an array holding the list items) and listLength (a variable indicating the current list length). What does the following function do?
void List::Mystery( ItemType alpha, bool& result )
{
int index = listLength - 1;
while (index >= 0 && alpha != listVals[index])
   index--;
result = (index >= 0);
}

Answer:
It searches a list for the last occurrence of a given item.

item.label: brg00139bb1fe2c19bf2_D78CF3EFC1AD4068B11553EEEB1F7C7C046
item.title: Suppose we have a List class with private data listVals (an array holding the list items) and listLength (a variable indicating the current list length). What does the following function do?

material.mattext:
Suppose we have a List class with private data listVals (an array holding the list items) and listLength (a variable indicating the current list length). What does the following function do?
void List::Mystery( ItemType alpha )
{
listVals[listLength] = alpha;
listLength++;
}

Answer:
It inserts a new item into an unsorted list.

item.label: brg00139bb1fe2c19bf2_A07FF8093F7F4FBD8FD06A49EE8693B8047
item.title: Suppose we have a List class with private data listVals (an array holding the list items) and listLength (a variable indicating the current list length). What does the following function do?

material.mattext:
Suppose we have a List class with private data listVals (an array holding the list items) and listLength (a variable indicating the current list length). What does the following function do?
void List::Mystery()
{
ItemType beta;
int      count1;
int      count2;
int      i;
for (count1 = 0; count1 < listLength - 1; count1++)
{
   i = count1;
   for (count2 = count1 + 1; count2 < listLength; count2++)
     if (listVals[count2] > listVals[i])
       i = count2;
   beta = listVals[i];
   listVals[i] = listVals[count1];
   listVals[count1] = beta;
}
}

Answer:
It sorts a list into descending order.

item.label: brg00139bb1fe2c19bf2_25081F8E58F04B1A96DDD3053A1E788A049
item.title: A list currently contains listLength integer items stored in an array listVals. Write a code segment that correctly inserts the value 100 into the list at position insertPos.

material.mattext: A list currently contains listLength integer items stored in an array listVals. Write a code segment that correctly inserts the value 100 into the list at position insertPos.

Answer:
for (i = listLength - 1; i >= insertPos; i--)
listVals[i+1] = listVals[i];
listVals[insertPos] = 100;
or
for (i = listLength; i > insertPos; i--)
listVals[i] = listVals[i-1];
listVals[insertPos] = 100;

item.title: Is a binary search always more efficient than a sequential search?

material.mattext: Is a binary search always more efficient than a sequential search?

Answer:
No. A binary search is more complex, so it takes more time to execute each iteration. If the list to be searched is short, a sequential search may be faster.

item.label: brg00139bb1fe2c19bf2_8FA4FB9B4C2D4F5B86CC7369DE6C627E059
item.title: Why are functions Reset and GetNextItem called an iterator pair and how do they operate?

material.mattext: Why are functions Reset and GetNextItem called an iterator pair and how do they operate?

Answer:
Reset initializes currentPos for a traversal of the list. GetNextItem returns the item at the currentPos position and increments currentPos. When the last item has been returned, currentPos is reset to the beginning of the list. The two functions must be used as a pair. GetNextItem, the iterator, will not work correctly if Reset has not been called.

passing a class object as an argument using a pass by value

class Fribbit
{
public:
.
.    // Some public operations
.
Fribbit( /* in */ char* initialString,

private:
char* str;
int   n;
};

item.title: All of the following are characteristic of a dynamic linked list EXCEPT:

material.mattext: All of the following are characteristic of a dynamic linked list EXCEPT:
A dynamic linked list can expand or contract as the program executes
To allocate a new item into the list, a compiler program allocates more space from the free store
To delete an item, a programmer deallocates the memory assigned to the item.
It is unnecessary to know in advance how many items the list will hold.
Available memory space is NOT a limitation on the size of the list.

int alpha = 35;

item.title: If ptr is a variable that points to an object of type

material.mattext:
If ptr is a variable that points to an object of type
struct InventoryType
{
    int   quantity;
    float itemCost;
} ;
write an expression that accesses the itemCost member of the object pointed to by ptr.

Answer:
Any of the three below correctly access the itemCost member.
(*ptr).itemCost
*ptr.itemCost
ptr->itemCost

item.label: brg001430f1fe2c19bf2_E5D21755F6F04228B735D18E874D5BC3060
item.title: When is a C++ copy-constructor implicitly invoked?

material.mattext: When is a C++ copy-constructor implicitly invoked?

Answer:
When a class object is initialized in its declaration by another class object and when a class object is passed as an argument using a pass by value.

item.label: brg001430f1fe2c19bf2_21B7E07554A945A38833BC56BCAA918E061

material.mattext: If a C++ class object points to dynamic data and the class has no destructor, what happens when the class object is destroyed?

Answer:
The result is a memory leak.

Answer:
a destructor, a copy-constructor, and a deep copy operation

item.label: brg001430f1fe2c19bf2_65DB670E5E2C46D19A46BE0CBD7A8001065
item.title: Distinguish between a deep copy and a shallow copy.

material.mattext: Distinguish between a deep copy and a shallow copy.

Answer:
A shallow copy is one in which each data field is copied exactly. A deep copy is one in which non-pointer fields are copied exactly and pointer field have what they point to copied.

item.label: brg001430f1fe2c19bf2_B4016D3CCD2A4A098A4DCBF8F4D46E2E066
item.title: When should dynamic data be destroyed?

material.mattext: When should dynamic data be destroyed?

Answer:
Any time during the execution of a program when the dynamic data is no longer needed.

item.label: brg001430f1fe2c19bf2_9B74B74AAED147068DF5DB335E8EB36D067
item.title: Define linked list

material.mattext:
Answer:
A linked list is a data structure in which the components are logically next to each other, instead of physically next to each other as they are in an array. A linked list can be represented as a collection of dynamic nodes, linked together by pointers.

item.title: Suppose that a C++ class D is derived from a base class B. Class B has a public member function Func() that is declared to be virtual, and class D reimplements Func(). At execution time, suppose that a D object is passed to the following function:

material.mattext:
Suppose that a C++ class D is derived from a base class B. Class B has a public member function Func() that is declared to be virtual, and class D reimplements Func(). At execution time, suppose that a D object is passed to the following function:
void DoSomething( B& x )
{
x.Func();
}
Within the DoSomething function, whose version of Func() is called?

item.label: brg00156561fe2c19bf2_7015E9C67C8B479D8A6A0E71DAF34D89057
item.title: Define responsibility and distinguish between an action responsibility and a knowledge responsibility.

material.mattext: Define responsibility and distinguish between an action responsibility and a knowledge responsibility.

Answer:
A responsibility is an operation implemented as a function. An action responsibility performs some action on or with an object. A knowledge responsibility returns the state of a private data member of an object.

Answer:

material.mattext: Suppose the main function has no exception handlers and calls function A. Function A has exception handlers for exceptions of type X and Y, and it calls function B. Function B has no exception handlers. If function B throws an exception of type Y, what happens?
The rest of the code in function B completes its execution, and then control transfers to an exception handler in function A.
Control exits function B immediately and transfers to the main function.
Control exits function B immediately and transfers to an exception handler in function A.
The program terminates immediately with an error message.

The rest of the code in function B completes its execution, and then control transfers to an exception handler in function A.

material.mattext:
Consider the following function:
void Func( int i, int j, int k )
{
try
{
   DoSomething(i, j, k);
}
catch ( ... )
{
   cout << "Whoops." << endl;
}
catch ( BadArgs )
{
   cout << "Invalid arguments." << endl;
}
cout << "All done." << endl;
}
If the DoSomething function throws a BadArgs exception and doesn't handle the exception, what is output by the function above?

item.title: Given the declarations

material.mattext:
Given the declarations
struct ListNode
{
float     volume;
ListNode* link;
};
ListNode* headPtr;
ListNode* ptr;
assume that headPtr is the external pointer to a linked list of many nodes. Write a code segment that outputs the data in the list, visiting each node from first to last.

Answer:
ptr = headPtr;
while (ptr != NULL)
{
cout << ptr->volume << endl;
ptr = ptr->link;
}

item.label: brg0017dcd1fe2c19bf3_5E097E1BDD814B17954DD230D3B55342071
item.title: Describe the function of an iterator operating in the STL

material.mattext: Describe the function of an iterator operating in the STL

Answer:
In the STL, an iterator is an object that points to some place in a container. An iterator provides extra functionality including operations that cause it to move in a step-by-step fashion through an STL container. Iterators come in two types: forward or reverse.

item.title: Given the recursive function

material.mattext:
Given the recursive function
int Func( /* in */ int i,
         /* in */ int j )
{
if (i < 11)
   if (j < 11)
     return i + j;
   else
     return j + Func(i, j - 2);
else
   return i + Func(i - 1, j);
}
the recursion stops when
i and j are both less than 11
either i or j is less than 11

item.label: brg00181061fe2c19bf3_C5E5127644264E1FB078BA6FD7976050038
item.title: In the following recursive function, which line(s) represent the base case?

material.mattext:
In the following recursive function, which line(s) represent the base case?
void PrintIt( /* in */ int n )    // Line 1
{                                           // Line 2
if (n == 0)                  // Line 3
   cout << n << endl;            // Line 4
else                                      // Line 5
{                                         // Line 6
   cout << "Again" << endl;        // Line 7
   PrintIt(n - 1);                    // Line 8
}
}

}
}

item.label: brg00181061fe2c19bf3_8675F546FC8D46A8A30838FF89CAF49F042
item.title: Given the recursive function

material.mattext:
Given the recursive function
int Func( /* in */ int n )
{
if (n == 5)
   return 5;
else
   return 2 * Func(n + 1);
}
what is the value of the expression Func(2) ?

item.label: brg00181061fe2c19bf3_1EEB243D4BBB445F848DC409FACD4C9D043
item.title: If the following function is called with a value of 73 for n, what is the resulting output?

material.mattext:
If the following function is called with a value of 73 for n, what is the resulting output?
void Func( /* in */ int n )
{
if (n > 0)
{
   Func(n / 5);
   cout << n % 5;
}
}

item.label: brg00181061fe2c19bf3_50BCC5B6D82E49E1AB848008CC7A0B4E044
item.title: The following function sums the integers from low through limit, inclusive:

material.mattext:
The following function sums the integers from low through limit, inclusive:
int Sum( /* in */ int low,
        /* in */ int limit )
{
if (           )   // ⇓---Condition is missing
   return limit;
else
   return low + Sum(low + 1, limit);
}
What is the missing If condition?

item.label: brg00181061fe2c19bf3_C440670102874D93B1C0D607546AC24E045
item.title: Given the recursive function

material.mattext:
Given the recursive function
void PrintArr( /* in */ const int arr[],
              /* in */       int first,
              /* in */       int last )
{
if (first > last)
   cout << "Done";
else
{
   PrintArr(arr, first + 1, last);
   cout << arr[first];
}
}
Write an iterative segment that produces the same output as the following function call.
   PrintArr(arr, 0, 5);

item.label: brg00181061fe2c19bf3_D37D3AB920654C778A57D867E1CF53DE046
item.title: If the following function is called with a value of 3 for n, what is the resulting output?

material.mattext:
If the following function is called with a value of 3 for n, what is the resulting output?
void TapDance( /* in */ int n )
{
if (n > -1)
{
   TapDance(n - 1);
   cout << "Flap";
}
else
   cout << "Shuffle";
}

item.label: brg00181061fe2c19bf3_DDC5E428676A42DFBD353CF9D9F91B01047
item.title: If the following function is called with a value of 4 for i, what is the resulting output?

material.mattext:
If the following function is called with a value of 4 for i, what is the resulting output?
void Test( /* in */ int i )
{
if (i < 8)
{
   Test(i + 1);
   cout << i << ' ';
}
}

item.label: brg00181061fe2c19bf3_5D4407D771EB49479CE16EFBE9BFA066048
item.title: Given the recursive function

material.mattext:
Given the recursive function
int Sum( /* in */ int n )
{
if (n < 8)
   return n + Sum(n + 1);
else
   return 2;
}
what is the value of the expression Sum(5)?

int Sum( /* in */ int n )

if (n < 8)

else
   return 2;
}
what is the value of the expression Sum(5)?

item.label: brg00181061fe2c19bf3_E96598A6CBC04E9DABFCA21BB2D35314050
item.title: If the following function is called with a value of 2 for n, what is the resulting output?

material.mattext:
If the following function is called with a value of 2 for n, what is the resulting output?
void Quiz( /* in */ int n )
{
if (n > 0)
{
   cout << 0;
   Quiz(n - 1);
   cout << 1;
   Quiz(n - 1);
}
}

item.label: brg00181061fe2c19bf3_62125FD511AB4BB582638C5E7D565F9D051
item.title: Given the recursive function

material.mattext:
Given the recursive function
int Func( /* in */ int i,
         /* in */ int j )
{
if (i < 11)
   if (j < 11)
     return i + j;
   else
     return j + Func(i, j - 2);
else
   return i + Func(i - 1, j);
}
what is the value of the expression Func(12, 15) ?

item.label: brg00181061fe2c19bf3_CE59749A13D04676BDCAB0A335FD87DC052
item.title: Given the following function, what is the value of the expression Func(2)?

material.mattext:
Given the following function, what is the value of the expression Func(2)?
int Func( /* in */ int n )
{
if (n != 5)
   return 3 + Func(n + 1);
else
   return 5;
}

item.label: brg00181061fe2c19bf3_F769B98A3C3F479CA85BAC654F7E431B054
item.title: Given the declaration

material.mattext:
Given the declaration
struct NodeType
{
int       data;
NodeType* next;
};
the following recursive function computes the sum of the components in a linked list:
int Sum( /* in */ NodeType* ptr)
{
if (ptr == NULL)
   <-- Statement is missing here
else
   return ptr->data + Sum(ptr->next);
}
What is the missing statement in the then-clause?

item.label: brg00181061fe2c19bf3_959A33D12C76470B92A6F03269547FBA055
item.title: Given the following function, what is the value of the expression Func(3) ?

material.mattext:
Given the following function, what is the value of the expression Func(3) ?
int Func( /* in */ int n )
{
if (n == 0)
   return 0;
else if (n == 1)
   return 1;
else
   return Func(n - 1) + Func(n - 2);
}

item.label: brg00181061fe2c19bf3_D530F6861BE641F6938B4F801119FE4E056
item.title: Given the following function, what is the value of the expression Func(6)?

material.mattext:
Given the following function, what is the value of the expression Func(6)?
int Func( /* in */ int n )
{
if (n == 0)
   return 0;
else if (n == 1)
   return 1;
else
   return Func(n - 1) + Func(n - 2);
}

Answer:
The case for which an answer is known.

item.label: brg00181061fe2c19bf3_D579C0F15CFC4B1EBF1FEC07CE99E25C057
item.title: What is the recursive (or general) case in a recursive solution?

material.mattext: What is the recursive (or general) case in a recursive solution?

Answer:
The recursive (or general) case in a recursive solution is the case expressed in terms of a smaller version of the original problem.

item.label: brg00181061fe2c19bf3_282C2AB698544BABBCAE4901F53B5B55058
item.title: Define tail recursion.

material.mattext:
Answer:
Tail recursion is a recursive algorithm in which no action is taken after the return from the recursive call.
